verses.text: Then Jesus said to his disciples, 'It is impossible for stumbling blocks not to come, but woe to the one through whom they come!'
verses.comment: Jesus warns that temptations to sin are unavoidable in a fallen world, but emphasizes responsibility for leading others into sin. Compare Matthew 18:7. The language of 'woe' mirrors Old Testament prophetic judgment, underscoring Christ's divine authority (cf. Isaiah 5:20).

verses.text: It would be better for him if a millstone were hung around his neck and he were thrown into the sea than for him to cause one of these little ones to stumble.
verses.comment: The severity of this warning shows the great value Jesus places on the innocent and vulnerable, especially in the context of faith. 'Little ones' can mean literal children or young believers. See also Matthew 18:6; Jesus’ judgment language echoes Old Testament warnings (Deut. 27:25).

verses.text: Keep watch over yourselves! If your brother sins, rebuke him; and if he repents, forgive him.
verses.comment: Jesus commands both accountability and mercy within his community. The instruction to 'rebuke' assumes loving correction, and forgiveness when repentance occurs. This two-fold approach is foundational for living out true Christian unity and holiness.

verses.text: And if he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times returns to you saying, 'I repent,' you must forgive him.
verses.comment: Unceasing forgiveness is an attribute of God (Psalm 86:5), and Christ instructs his followers to imitate divine mercy without limit, anticipating the fuller teaching on forgiveness given in the Lord’s Prayer (Matt. 6:12-14).

verses.text: The apostles said to the Lord, 'Increase our faith!'
verses.comment: Recognizing the difficulty of such constant forgiveness, the disciples appeal to Jesus for greater faith. Their address, 'Lord,' is an acknowledgment of Christ's authority and hints at his divinity (see also Luke 5:8; John 20:28).

verses.text: And the Lord said, 'If you have faith the size of a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree, "Be uprooted and planted in the sea," and it would obey you.'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches that even a small amount of genuine faith, when united to God’s will, can accomplish the impossible. The 'Lord' designation again points to Christ’s divine authority. See cross-references to Matthew 17:20. The mulberry tree symbolizes deeply rooted difficulties overcome by faith.

verses.text: 'Suppose one of you has a servant plowing or tending sheep. When he comes in from the field, will he say to him, “Come at once and sit down to eat”?'
verses.comment: This imagery reflects the ancient practice where servants performed their master’s will before expecting reward (cf. Matt. 25:21). The analogy sets up a teaching about humility and recognizing God’s sovereign rights over his servants.

verses.text: Will he not rather say to him, 'Prepare my supper, and dress yourself to serve me while I eat and drink, and afterward you may eat and drink'?
verses.comment: Jesus stresses the duty of service to God that precedes personal reward. The structure of this analogy may allude to the true hierarchy of the Kingdom (Matt. 20:26-28).

verses.text: Does he thank the servant because he did what was commanded?
verses.comment: The implied answer is 'No.' The passage teaches that obedience to God is a basic expectation, not something praiseworthy in itself; it encourages humility in discipleship, a major theme in Luke’s Gospel.

verses.text: In the same way, when you have done everything commanded of you, say, 'We are unworthy servants; we have only done our duty.'
verses.comment: This verse expresses the need for humility, recognizing that all good works are merely the fulfillment of what is already owed to God. The term 'unworthy servants' supports doctrines of grace over any claim to merit before God, and reflects a proper spiritual attitude of ongoing conversion.

verses.text: As Jesus was traveling toward Jerusalem, he passed through the midst of Samaria and Galilee.
verses.comment: The journey to Jerusalem sets the context for his mission and coming sacrifice (see Luke 9:51). Passing through Samaria foreshadows Jesus' teaching that salvation is for all people, fulfilling Old Testament prophecies of the Messiah as Savior of both Jew and Gentile (Isaiah 49:6).

verses.text: As he entered a village, ten men who had leprosy met him. They stood at a distance,
verses.comment: Leprosy, a symbol of spiritual uncleanness, required separation from the community (Leviticus 13:45-46). Their distance conveys both physical and ritual separation according to Mosaic Law.

verses.text: and they raised their voices, saying, 'Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!'
verses.comment: Calling Jesus 'Master' reveals their recognition of his authority. Their plea for mercy echoes common language in Psalms (Ps. 123:3) and anticipates later expressions of Christian prayer for mercy.

verses.text: When he saw them, he said, 'Go and show yourselves to the priests.' And as they went, they were cleansed.
verses.comment: Jesus asks for obedience to Mosaic Law by sending them to the priests (Leviticus 14:2). Their healing comes as they obey his command, illustrating the relationship between faith, obedience, and healing.

verses.text: One of them, seeing that he was healed, turned back, glorifying God with a loud voice.
verses.comment: Giving glory to God is the proper response to divine intervention (see Psalm 107:22). The returning leper’s worship sets the example for how all should respond to God’s grace.

verses.text: He fell on his face at Jesus' feet, thanking him—and he was a Samaritan.
verses.comment: The posture of falling at Jesus’ feet reflects adoration and possibly worship. That this man was a Samaritan highlights the Messianic fulfillment for outsiders and the universal scope of Christ’s saving work.

verses.text: Then Jesus answered, 'Were not ten cleansed? Where are the nine?'
verses.comment: A rhetorical question that reveals the differences in gratitude and recognition of God’s work in Jesus. Only the Samaritan returns, emphasizing themes of faith and true worship beyond ethnic or religious barriers.

verses.text: Was no one found to return and give praise to God except this foreigner?'
verses.comment: Jesus commends the Samaritan’s faith and gratitude. The term 'foreigner' highlights God's plan to invite all peoples into true worship, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy (Isaiah 56:6-7).

verses.text: Then he said to him, 'Rise and go your way; your faith has saved you.'
verses.comment: The Greek verb 'has saved you' (σέσωκέν σε) can signify both physical healing and spiritual salvation, suggesting a sacramental dimension—faith opening a person to deeper, saving grace through encounter with Christ.

verses.text: Being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, he answered them, 'The kingdom of God is not coming in ways that can be observed,'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches the mysterious, unseen arrival of the kingdom—contrary to the Pharisees' expectations of a visible, political event. This hidden aspect is fulfilled in the presence of Christ and the establishment of his Church on earth.

verses.text: nor will they say, ‘Look, here it is!’ or ‘There!’ For behold, the kingdom of God is in your midst.'
verses.comment: Christ himself brings the kingdom into their midst (Greek: 'entos hymōn'—within you/among you). This speaks to a spiritual reality founded in the person of Jesus and the new covenant community (see Jeremiah 31:33).

verses.text: Then he said to the disciples, 'The days are coming when you will long to see one of the days of the Son of Man, and you will not see it.'
verses.comment: The title 'Son of Man' alludes to Daniel 7:13 and is a messianic, divine title. Jesus predicts a time of longing for his presence after his ascension, anticipating the period of growth and suffering for the Church.

verses.text: And they will say to you, ‘Look, there!’ or ‘Look, here!’ Do not go after them or follow them.
verses.comment: Jesus warns against false claimants during the time of his apparent absence. The caution is to remain faithful to apostolic teaching rather than chasing after new revelations or self-proclaimed messiahs.

verses.text: For as the lightning flashes and lights up the sky from one side to the other, so will the Son of Man be in his day.
verses.comment: The return of Christ will be sudden, universal, and unmistakable, in contrast to secret or hidden arrivals. This passage shapes traditional Christian eschatology concerning the Second Coming.

verses.text: But first he must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.
verses.comment: Messianic suffering is a fulfillment of prophecy (Isaiah 53:3). Jesus links his identity as the 'Son of Man' with a suffering servant, essential for salvation history prior to his return in glory.

verses.text: Just as it was in the days of Noah, so it will be in the days of the Son of Man:
verses.comment: The comparison to Noah emphasizes sudden judgment amidst normal life. Christ draws on Genesis history as a type for his return and final judgment.

verses.text: They were eating, drinking, marrying and being given in marriage, until the day Noah entered the ark, and the flood came and destroyed them all.
verses.comment: Ordinary activities continued right up to the moment of judgment. The 'ark' prefigures the Church as a means of salvation through coming judgment (cf. 1 Peter 3:20-21).

verses.text: Similarly, just as it was in the days of Lot—they were eating and drinking, buying and selling, planting and building—
verses.comment: Lot’s days are another example of sudden divine judgment amidst worldly pursuits. Genesis 19 provides the Old Testament background.

verses.text: but on the day Lot left Sodom, fire and sulfur rained from heaven and destroyed them all.
verses.comment: The divine destruction of Sodom is a type for the final judgment. Jude 7 also interprets this event as future warning for those who live apart from God’s commands.

verses.text: 'It will be just the same on the day when the Son of Man is revealed.'
verses.comment: The final revelation of Christ, the 'Son of Man,' will result in immediate and decisive judgment. Revelation 1:7 affirms that all will see him at his coming.

verses.text: 'On that day, let the one who is on the housetop, with his belongings in the house, not come down to take them away. And likewise, let the one in the field not turn back.'
verses.comment: Jesus warns against attachment to material goods at the time of final judgment or crisis. The urgency reflects total commitment to God, a standard for all disciples.

verses.text: 'Remember Lot’s wife.'
verses.comment: Lot’s wife was turned to salt for longing back while fleeing judgment, a warning not to look back or hesitate when God calls to salvation. Her fate is seen as a sign against spiritual compromise.

verses.text: 'Whoever seeks to preserve his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life will keep it.'
verses.comment: This paradox captures Jesus’ teaching on self-denial: giving up one’s own life for Christ leads to true life. It is an invitation to total trust and surrender in following the Lord—echoes are found throughout the Gospels.

verses.text: 'I tell you, in that night there will be two in one bed; one will be taken and the other left.'
verses.comment: This refrain reveals the sudden and personal nature of divine judgment and separation—no one is saved merely by association; it is a call for personal fidelity and readiness.

verses.text: 'There will be two women grinding together; one will be taken and the other left.'
verses.comment: The image of women grinding at the mill further illustrates the unexpected and decisive judgment at Christ’s coming. The call is to remain vigilant and faithful.

verses.text: [This verse not present in earliest manuscripts.]
verses.comment: Some later manuscripts add: 'Two men will be in the field; one will be taken, and the other left.' This is supported by Matthew 24:40 but is likely not original to Luke, illustrating how scribal additions occurred in the transmission process.

verses.text: And they answered him, 'Where, Lord?' He said to them, 'Where the body is, there also the vultures will gather.'
verses.comment: This proverbial saying points to the public and unmistakable nature of divine judgment. Just as vultures gather where there is a corpse, so the signs of the end will be evident to all. The disciples’ address, 'Lord,' again emphasizes Jesus’ divine status.
